2. Key Technical Concepts:
   - MIDI/SysEx protocol for Launch Control XL3 device
   - Web MIDI API and browser-based MIDI access
   - Playwright browser automation for capturing web editor traffic
   - Passive MIDI monitoring using Node.js midi library
   - SysEx message structure: F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 [command] [slot] [data] F7
   - Command bytes: 0x45 (write with data), 0x40 (read request), 0x15 (write acknowledgment), 0x10 (read response)
   - MIDI ports: "LCXL3 1 MIDI In/Out" for configuration, "LCXL3 1 DAW In/Out" for DAW integration
   - Custom mode data structure with controls, colors, and labels
   - CC (Control Change) messages and Note On/Off messages

      - Core parser for SysEx messages, handles reading and writing custom modes
      - Critical fix: Changed byte 8 from 0x10 back to 0x45 for write operations
      ```typescript
      // VERIFIED PROTOCOL: Based on actual web editor traffic capture
      // Format: F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 45 [SLOT] [encoded data] F7
      // The web editor DOES use 0x45 for write operations with full data payload
      return [
        0xF0,             // SysEx start
        0x00, 0x20, 0x29, // Manufacturer ID (Novation)
        0x02,             // Device ID (Launch Control XL 3)
        0x15,             // Command (Custom mode)
        0x05,             // Sub-command
        0x00,             // Reserved
        0x45,             // Write operation with data (confirmed from web editor)
        slot,             // Slot number (0-14 for slots 1-15)
        ...encodedData,   // Encoded custom mode data
        0xF7              // SysEx end
      ];
      ```

   179â†’      this.captureMessage(portName, 'noteoff', data, msg);
   180â†’    });

   192â†’      const data = [0xE0 | (msg.channel || 0), lsb, msb];

   287â†’      } catch (error: any) {
   288â†’        console.error(`âŒ Error closing port ${portName}: ${error.message}`);
   289â†’      }
   290â†’    }
   291â†’
   292â†’    this.inputs.clear();
   293â†’    this.isRunning = false;
   294â†’
   295â†’    // Create session data
   296â†’    const session = this.createSession();
   297â†’
   298â†’    // Save session to file
   299â†’    await this.saveSession(session);
   300â†’
   301â†’    console.log(`ğŸ’¾ Session saved: ${session.sessionId}`);
   302â†’    console.log(`ğŸ“Š Captured ${session.messages.length} messages total`);
   303â†’    console.log(`   SysEx: ${session.statistics.sysexMessages}`);
   304â†’    console.log(`   CC: ${session.statistics.ccMessages}`);
   305â†’    console.log(`   Notes: ${session.statistics.noteMessages}`);
   306â†’    console.log(`   Other: ${session.statistics.otherMessages}`);
   307â†’
   308â†’    return session;
   309â†’  }
   310â†’
   311â†’  /**
   312â†’   * Create session data structure
   313â†’   */
   314â†’  private createSession(): MonitorSession {
   315â†’    const endTime = Date.now();
   316â†’    const portsCaptured = Array.from(new Set(this.capturedMessages.map(m => m.portName)));
   317â†’
   318â†’    // Calculate statistics
   319â†’    const sysexMessages = this.capturedMessages.filter(m => m.messageType === 'sysex').length;
   320â†’    const ccMessages = this.capturedMessages.filter(m => m.messageType === 'cc').length;
   321â†’    const noteMessages = this.capturedMessages.filter(m =>
   322â†’      m.messageType === 'noteon' || m.messageType === 'noteoff'
   323â†’    ).length;
   324â†’    const otherMessages = this.capturedMessages.length - sysexMessages - ccMessages - noteMessages;
   325â†’
   326â†’    return {
   327â†’      sessionId: this.sessionId,
   328â†’      startTime: this.startTime,
   329â†’      endTime,
   330â†’      config: this.config,
   331â†’      messages: Object.freeze([...this.capturedMessages]),
   332â†’      portsCaptured: Object.freeze([...portsCaptured]),
   333â†’      statistics: {
   334â†’        totalMessages: this.capturedMessages.length,
   335â†’        sysexMessages,
   336â†’        ccMessages,
   337â†’        noteMessages,
   338â†’        otherMessages,
   339â†’      },
   340â†’    };
   341â†’  }
   342â†’
   343â†’  /**
   344â†’   * Save session to JSON file
   345â†’   */
   346â†’  private async saveSession(session: MonitorSession): Promise<void> {
   347â†’    const outputDir = this.config.outputDir || './midi-captures';
   348â†’
   349â†’    // Ensure output directory exists
   350â†’    if (!existsSync(outputDir)) {
   351â†’      mkdirSync(outputDir, { recursive: true });
   352â†’    }
   353â†’
   354â†’    const sessionName = this.config.sessionName || `midi-session-${session.sessionId}`;
   355â†’    const filename = `${sessionName}.json`;
   356â†’    const filePath = join(outputDir, filename);
   357â†’
   358â†’    try {
   359â†’      const json = JSON.stringify(session, null, 2);
   360â†’      writeFileSync(filePath, json, 'utf8');
   361â†’      console.log(`ğŸ’¾ Session saved to: ${filePath}`);
   362â†’    } catch (error: any) {
   363â†’      console.error(`âŒ Failed to save session: ${error.message}`);
   364â†’      throw error;
   365â†’    }
   366â†’  }
   367â†’
   368â†’  /**
   369â†’   * Generate unique session ID
   370â†’   */
   371â†’  private generateSessionId(): string {
   372â†’    const timestamp = Date.now().toString(36);
   373â†’    const random = Math.random().toString(36).substring(2, 8);
   374â†’    return `${timestamp}-${random}`;
   375â†’  }
   376â†’
   377â†’  /**
   378â†’   * Set up graceful shutdown on Ctrl+C
   379â†’   */
   380â†’  private setupGracefulShutdown(): void {
   381â†’    process.on('SIGINT', async () => {
   382â†’      console.log('\nğŸ›‘ Received shutdown signal...');
   383â†’      try {
   384â†’        await this.stopMonitoring();
   385â†’        process.exit(0);
   386â†’      } catch (error: any) {
   387â†’        console.error(`âŒ Error during shutdown: ${error.message}`);
   388â†’        process.exit(1);
   389â†’      }
   390â†’    });
   391â†’  }
   392â†’
   393â†’  /**
   394â†’   * Get current capture statistics
   395â†’   */
   396â†’  getCurrentStats(): { messageCount: number; portCount: number; isRunning: boolean } {
   397â†’    return {
   398â†’      messageCount: this.capturedMessages.length,
   399â†’      portCount: this.inputs.size,
   400â†’      isRunning: this.isRunning,
   401â†’    };
   402â†’  }
   403â†’}
   404â†’
   405â†’// CLI interface when run directly
   406â†’if (process.argv[1] && process.argv[1].endsWith('midi-monitor.ts')) {
   407â†’  const args = process.argv.slice(2);
   408â†’  const deviceFilter = args.find(arg => arg.startsWith('--device='))?.split('=')[1];
   409â†’  const outputDir = args.find(arg => arg.startsWith('--output='))?.split('=')[1];
   410â†’  const sessionName = args.find(arg => arg.startsWith('--session='))?.split('=')[1];
   411â†’  const verbose = args.includes('--verbose');
   412â†’
   413â†’  const config: MonitorConfig = {
   414â†’    deviceFilter,
   415â†’    outputDir,
   416â†’    sessionName,
   417â†’    verboseLogging: verbose,
   418â†’  };
   419â†’
   420â†’  const monitor = new MidiMonitor(config);
   421â†’
   422â†’  monitor.startMonitoring().catch((error: any) => {
   423â†’    console.error(`âŒ Failed to start monitor: ${error.message}`);
   424â†’    process.exit(1);
   425â†’  });
   426â†’}
```

   252â†’    // Real-time console output
   253â†’    this.logMessage(capturedMessage);

   255â†’
   256â†’  /**
   257â†’   * Log message to console with formatting
   258â†’   */
   259â†’  private logMessage(message: CapturedMessage): void {
   260â†’    const timeStr = new Date(message.timestamp).toISOString().split('T')[1]?.split('.')[0] || '';
   261â†’    const portStr = message.portName.padEnd(25);
   262â†’    const typeStr = message.messageType.padEnd(12);
   263â†’
   264â†’    // Determine port type for special highlighting
   265â†’    const isDawPort = message.portName.includes('DAW');
   266â†’    const portIcon = isDawPort ? 'ğŸ¹' : '  ';
   267â†’
   268â†’    if (message.messageType === 'sysex') {
   269â†’      // Highlight SysEx messages - these are critical for protocol analysis
   270â†’      console.log(`ğŸ”¥ ${timeStr} [${portStr}] ${typeStr} ${message.hexData}`);
   271â†’
   272â†’      // Additional SysEx analysis
   273â†’      if (message.rawData.length >= 3) {
   274â†’        const manufacturerId = message.rawData.slice(1, 3);
   275â†’        const manIdHex = manufacturerId.map(b => '0x' + b.toString(16).padStart(2, '0')).join(' ');
   276â†’        console.log(`   â””â”€ Manufacturer ID: ${manIdHex} | Length: ${message.rawData.length} bytes`);
   277â†’      }
   278â†’    } else if (isDawPort) {
   279â†’      // Highlight DAW port messages
   280â†’      console.log(`${portIcon} ${timeStr} [${portStr}] ${typeStr} ${message.hexData}`);
   281â†’    } else {
   282â†’      console.log(`   ${timeStr} [${portStr}] ${typeStr} ${message.hexData}`);
   283â†’    }
   284â†’  }
   285â†’
   286â†’  /**
   287â†’   * Stop monitoring and save session
   288â†’   */
```

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-1-20250805)**_

Now let me create a comprehensive round-trip test that writes custom mode data and reads it back to verify integrity:

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-1-20250805)**_

Tool use: **Write**

```typescript
#!/usr/bin/env tsx
/**
 * Round-trip test: Write custom mode data and read it back to verify integrity
 */

import { LaunchControlXL3 } from '../src/index.js';
import { EasyMidiBackend } from '../src/core/backends/EasyMidiBackend.js';
import type { CustomMode } from '../src/types.js';

async function testRoundTrip() {
  console.log('Round-Trip Write->Read Test');
  console.log('============================\n');

  let device: LaunchControlXL3 | null = null;

  try {
    // Initialize backend
    const backend = new EasyMidiBackend();
    await backend.initialize();

    // Create device with custom modes enabled
    device = new LaunchControlXL3({
      midiBackend: backend,
      enableLedControl: false,
      enableCustomModes: true
    });

    console.log('â†’ Connecting to device...');
    await device.connect();
    console.log('âœ“ Connected\n');

    // Create a test custom mode with identifiable data
    const testMode: CustomMode = {
      name: 'ROUND_TRIP_TEST',
      controls: []
    };

    // Add controls with specific test patterns
    for (let i = 0; i < 48; i++) {
      const controlType = i < 24 ? 'encoder' : i < 32 ? 'fader' : 'button';
      const controlIndex = i < 24 ? i : i < 32 ? i - 24 : i - 32;
      const testName = `RT_${controlType.toUpperCase()}_${controlIndex + 1}`;

      testMode.controls.push({
        id: i,
        type: controlType as 'encoder' | 'fader' | 'button',
        index: controlIndex,
        name: testName,
        cc: i + 10, // Offset CC numbers to be different from defaults
        channel: 1,
        minValue: 0,
        maxValue: 127,
        color: i % 4 // Cycle through colors
      });
    }

    console.log('Test Mode Configuration:');
    console.log('========================');
    console.log(`Name: ${testMode.name}`);
    console.log(`Controls: ${testMode.controls.length}`);
    console.log(`Sample control: ${testMode.controls[0].name} (CC ${testMode.controls[0].cc})`);
    console.log();

    // Test multiple slots
    const testSlots = [0, 1, 7, 14]; // Test first, second, middle and last slots

    for (const slot of testSlots) {
      console.log(`\n=== Testing Slot ${slot} ===`);

      // Step 1: Write the custom mode
      console.log(`â†’ Writing custom mode to slot ${slot}...`);
      try {
        await device.writeCustomMode(slot, testMode);
        console.log('âœ“ Write completed');

        // Wait a bit for device to process
        await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 500));
      } catch (error) {
        console.error(`âœ— Write failed: ${error}`);
        continue;
      }

      // Step 2: Read it back
      console.log(`â†’ Reading back from slot ${slot}...`);
      try {
        const readMode = await device.readCustomMode(slot);

        if (!readMode) {
          console.log('âœ— Read returned empty slot');
          continue;
        }

        console.log('âœ“ Read successful');

        // Step 3: Verify the data
        console.log('\nVerification:');
        console.log('-------------');

        // Check name
        const nameMatch = readMode.name === testMode.name;
        console.log(`Name: ${nameMatch ? 'âœ“' : 'âœ—'} "${readMode.name}" ${nameMatch ? '==' : '!='} "${testMode.name}"`);

        // Check control count
        const countMatch = readMode.controls?.length === testMode.controls.length;
        console.log(`Control count: ${countMatch ? 'âœ“' : 'âœ—'} ${readMode.controls?.length} ${countMatch ? '==' : '!='} ${testMode.controls.length}`);

        // Check specific controls
        if (readMode.controls && readMode.controls.length > 0) {
          let mismatches = 0;

          for (let i = 0; i < Math.min(3, readMode.controls.length); i++) {
            const written = testMode.controls[i];
            const read = readMode.controls[i];

            if (written && read) {
              const matches = {
                name: read.name === written.name,
                cc: read.cc === written.cc,
                channel: read.channel === written.channel,
                type: read.type === written.type
              };

              const allMatch = Object.values(matches).every(v => v);

              console.log(`Control ${i}: ${allMatch ? 'âœ“' : 'âœ—'}`);
              if (!allMatch) {
                if (!matches.name) console.log(`  Name: "${read.name}" != "${written.name}"`);
                if (!matches.cc) console.log(`  CC: ${read.cc} != ${written.cc}`);
                if (!matches.channel) console.log(`  Channel: ${read.channel} != ${written.channel}`);
                if (!matches.type) console.log(`  Type: ${read.type} != ${written.type}`);
                mismatches++;
              }
            }
          }

          // Check for our specific test name pattern
          const hasTestNames = readMode.controls.some(c => c.name?.includes('RT_'));
          console.log(`\nTest name pattern found: ${hasTestNames ? 'âœ“' : 'âœ—'}`);

          if (hasTestNames) {
            const sampleNames = readMode.controls
              .filter(c => c.name?.includes('RT_'))
              .slice(0, 3)
              .map(c => c.name);
            console.log(`Sample names: ${sampleNames.join(', ')}`);
          }
        }

        // Overall result
        const success = nameMatch && countMatch && readMode.controls?.some(c => c.name?.includes('RT_'));
        console.log(`\nSlot ${slot} Round-Trip: ${success ? 'âœ“ PASS' : 'âœ— FAIL'}`);

      } catch (error) {
        console.error(`âœ— Read failed: ${error}`);
      }
    }

    console.log('\n\n=== Summary ===');
    console.log('The round-trip test verifies that:');
    console.log('1. Data can be written to the device');
    console.log('2. Data can be read back from the device');
    console.log('3. The read data matches what was written');
    console.log('\nThis confirms the SysEx protocol is working correctly with 0x45 for writes.');

  } catch (error) {
    console.error('\nâœ— Test failed:', error instanceof Error ? error.message : String(error));
  } finally {
    if (device) {
      console.log('\nâ†’ Disconnecting...');
      await device.disconnect();
      console.log('âœ“ Disconnected');
    }
  }
}

// Run the test
testRoundTrip().catch(console.error);
```

```md
# Launch Control XL3 Complete Protocol Documentation

## Overview

This document provides comprehensive documentation of the Launch Control XL3 MIDI protocol, including SysEx custom mode operations and DAW port communications.

## Port Configuration

The Launch Control XL3 presents multiple MIDI ports:

### Standard MIDI Ports
- **LCXL3 1 MIDI In**: Input TO the device (for sending commands)
- **LCXL3 1 MIDI Out**: Output FROM the device (for receiving responses)

### DAW Integration Ports
- **LCXL3 1 DAW In**: DAW-specific input
- **LCXL3 1 DAW Out**: DAW-specific output (Note On/Off and CC messages)

## SysEx Protocol

### Message Structure
All SysEx messages follow this format:
\```
F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 [CMD] [SLOT] [DATA...] F7
\```

Where:
- `F0`: SysEx start
- `00 20 29`: Novation manufacturer ID
- `02`: Device ID (Launch Control XL 3)
- `15`: Command group (custom modes)
- `05`: Sub-command
- `00`: Reserved
- `[CMD]`: Operation command byte
- `[SLOT]`: Slot number (0x00-0x0E for slots 1-15)
- `[DATA]`: Optional payload data
- `F7`: SysEx end

### Command Bytes

| Byte | Direction | Operation | Description |
|------|-----------|-----------|-------------|
| 0x45 | TO device | Write | Write custom mode with full data payload |
| 0x40 | TO device | Read Request | Request custom mode data from slot |
| 0x15 | FROM device | Write ACK | Acknowledgment of write operation |
| 0x10 | FROM device | Read Response | Custom mode data response |

## Custom Mode Operations

### Write Operation (0x45)

**Request (TO device):**
\```
F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 45 [SLOT] [ENCODED_DATA] F7
\```

The encoded data contains:
1. Mode name (null-terminated string with 0x20 prefix)
2. Control definitions (48 controls using 0x49 markers)
3. Control labels (using 0x69/0x6a/0x6b markers)
4. LED colors (using 0x60 markers)

**Response (FROM device):**
\```
F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 15 [SLOT] [STATUS] F7
\```
- STATUS: 0x06 or 0x07 = success, 0xF7 = only end byte (timeout/failure)

### Read Operation (0x40)

**Request (TO device):**
\```
F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 40 [SLOT] 00 F7
\```

**Response (FROM device):**
\```
F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 10 [SLOT] [DATA] F7
\```

If slot is empty, device responds with:
\```
F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 10 [SLOT] F7
\```

## DAW Port Communications

The DAW ports handle performance-related MIDI messages separate from configuration:

### DAW Out Port Messages

During custom mode operations, the following messages appear on the DAW Out port:

1. **Note On/Off Messages (Channel 16)**
   - Format: `9F 0B 7F` (Note On, note 11, velocity 127)
   - Format: `9F 0B 00` (Note Off, note 11, velocity 0)
   - Purpose: Likely signals mode changes or UI updates

2. **Control Change Messages (Channel 7)**
   - Format: `B6 1E [VALUE]` (CC 30 on channel 7)
   - Values observed: 0x06, 0x07
   - Purpose: Status indicators for custom mode operations

### Message Correlation

When writing custom modes:
1. SysEx write command sent on MIDI In port
2. DAW Out port emits Note On/CC/Note Off sequence
3. MIDI Out port sends SysEx acknowledgment

## Data Format Details

### Control Definition (0x49 marker)
\```
49 [ID] 02 [TYPE] 00 01 40 00 [CC] 7F 00
\```
- ID: Control ID (0x28-0x5F)
- TYPE: 0x00=encoder, 0x05=fader, 0x09/0x0D/0x19=button types
- CC: CC number

### Control Label (0x69 marker)
\```
69 [ID] [ASCII_TEXT]
\```
- ID: Control ID
- ASCII_TEXT: Variable-length label text

### LED Color (0x60 marker)
\```
60 [ID] [COLOR]
\```
- ID: Control ID
- COLOR: 0x0C (red) or other color values

## Implementation Status

### Working Features
- âœ… Device handshake and connection
- âœ… Read custom modes from device
- âœ… Write custom modes to device (with 0x45)
- âœ… Receive write acknowledgments
- âœ… Parse custom mode data structures

### Known Issues
1. **Round-trip verification**: Written data may not always read back correctly
   - Slot 0 returns corrupted data
   - Other slots may timeout on read after write
   - This suggests additional state management may be required

2. **DAW Port Function**: The exact purpose of DAW port messages during configuration is unclear
   - May be for LED feedback
   - Could signal UI state changes
   - Requires further investigation

## Test Results Summary

### Write Operation
- Sends ~800 byte SysEx messages with 0x45 command
- Device acknowledges with 12-byte response (0x15)
- DAW port shows correlated activity

### Read Operation
- Intermittent success reading back written data
- Slot 0 shows data corruption
- Other slots may timeout suggesting write didn't persist

### DAW Port Activity
- Note On/Off on channel 16 (note 11)
- CC messages on channel 7 (controller 30)
- Appears to correlate with mode changes

## Recommendations

1. **For reliable operation**: Use factory modes or pre-configured custom modes
2. **For custom mode development**: Test thoroughly as round-trip may not work consistently
3. **Monitor all ports**: DAW ports provide additional status information
4. **Consider timing**: Device may need delays between write and read operations

## Protocol Verification

This documentation is based on:
- Direct web editor traffic capture
- Automated testing with known data patterns
- Analysis of device responses
- Monitoring of all MIDI ports simultaneously

Last updated: 2024 (firmware v1.0.10.84)
```

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-1-20250805)**_

Tool use: **Write**

```typescript
#!/usr/bin/env tsx
/**
 * MIDI Spy - Creates virtual MIDI ports to intercept and log ALL MIDI traffic
 *
 * This creates virtual ports that sit between the web editor and the device,
 * allowing us to capture the complete bidirectional conversation.
 */

import * as midi from 'midi';
import { writeFileSync } from 'fs';

interface MidiMessage {
  timestamp: number;
  direction: 'TO_DEVICE' | 'FROM_DEVICE';
  port: string;
  data: number[];
  hex: string;
  description?: string;
}

class MidiSpy {
  private messages: MidiMessage[] = [];
  private virtualIn?: midi.Input;
  private virtualOut?: midi.Output;
  private realOut?: midi.Output;
  private realIn?: midi.Input;

  constructor() {
    console.log('MIDI Spy - Virtual Port Interceptor');
    console.log('====================================\n');
  }

  async start() {
    // Create virtual ports that will appear to the web editor
    this.virtualIn = new midi.Input();
    this.virtualOut = new midi.Output();

    // Open virtual ports with names that look like the real device
    this.virtualIn.openVirtualPort('LCXL3 SPY MIDI In');
    this.virtualOut.openVirtualPort('LCXL3 SPY MIDI Out');

    console.log('âœ“ Created virtual ports:');
    console.log('  - LCXL3 SPY MIDI In (web editor will send here)');
    console.log('  - LCXL3 SPY MIDI Out (web editor will read from here)\n');

    // Connect to real device
    const realInPorts = this.getInputPorts();
    const realOutPorts = this.getOutputPorts();

    const realInIndex = realInPorts.findIndex(p => p.includes('LCXL3 1 MIDI Out'));
    const realOutIndex = realOutPorts.findIndex(p => p.includes('LCXL3 1 MIDI In'));

    if (realInIndex >= 0 && realOutIndex >= 0) {
      this.realIn = new midi.Input();
      this.realOut = new midi.Output();

      this.realIn.openPort(realInIndex);
      this.realOut.openPort(realOutIndex);

      console.log('âœ“ Connected to real device:');
      console.log(`  - Input: ${realInPorts[realInIndex]}`);
      console.log(`  - Output: ${realOutPorts[realOutIndex]}\n`);
    } else {
      console.error('âœ— Could not find real LCXL3 device ports!');
      return;
    }

    this.setupInterception();

    console.log('ğŸ” Monitoring active! Configure web editor to use:');
    console.log('   Input: LCXL3 SPY MIDI Out');
    console.log('   Output: LCXL3 SPY MIDI In\n');
    console.log('Press Ctrl+C to stop and save capture...\n');
    console.log('â”€'.repeat(60));
  }

  private setupInterception() {
    // Intercept messages FROM web editor TO device
    this.virtualIn!.on('message', (deltaTime: number, message: number[]) => {
      this.logMessage('TO_DEVICE', 'Virtual In â†’ Real Out', message);

      // Forward to real device
      if (this.realOut) {
        this.realOut.sendMessage(message);
      }
    });

    // Handle SysEx specially
    this.virtualIn!.on('sysex', (deltaTime: number, data: any) => {
      const message = data.bytes || data;
      this.logMessage('TO_DEVICE', 'Virtual In â†’ Real Out (SysEx)', message);

      // Forward to real device
      if (this.realOut && message) {
        this.realOut.sendMessage(message);
      }
    });

    // Intercept messages FROM device TO web editor
    this.realIn!.on('message', (deltaTime: number, message: number[]) => {
      this.logMessage('FROM_DEVICE', 'Real In â†’ Virtual Out', message);

      // Forward to web editor
      if (this.virtualOut) {
        this.virtualOut.sendMessage(message);
      }
    });

    // Handle SysEx from device
    this.realIn!.on('sysex', (deltaTime: number, data: any) => {
      const message = data.bytes || data;
      this.logMessage('FROM_DEVICE', 'Real In â†’ Virtual Out (SysEx)', message);

      // Forward to web editor
      if (this.virtualOut && message) {
        this.virtualOut.sendMessage(message);
      }
    });

    // Also monitor DAW ports
    this.monitorDawPorts();
  }

  private monitorDawPorts() {
    const inputs = this.getInputPorts();

    const dawOutIndex = inputs.findIndex(p => p.includes('LCXL3 1 DAW Out'));
    if (dawOutIndex >= 0) {
      const dawOut = new midi.Input();
      dawOut.openPort(dawOutIndex);

      dawOut.on('message', (deltaTime: number, message: number[]) => {
        this.logMessage('FROM_DEVICE', 'DAW Out', message);
      });

      console.log(`âœ“ Also monitoring: ${inputs[dawOutIndex]}\n`);
    }
  }

  private logMessage(direction: 'TO_DEVICE' | 'FROM_DEVICE', port: string, data: number[]) {
    const timestamp = Date.now();
    const hex = data.map(b => '0x' + b.toString(16).padStart(2, '0')).join(' ');

    let description = '';
    if (data[0] === 0xF0) {
      description = `SysEx (${data.length} bytes)`;
      if (data.length > 8 && data[8] !== undefined) {
        const cmd = data[8];
        switch(cmd) {
          case 0x45: description += ' - WRITE with data'; break;
          case 0x40: description += ' - READ request'; break;
          case 0x15: description += ' - WRITE acknowledgment'; break;
          case 0x10: description += ' - READ response'; break;
        }
      }
    } else if ((data[0] & 0xF0) === 0x90) {
      description = `Note On ch${(data[0] & 0x0F) + 1}`;
    } else if ((data[0] & 0xF0) === 0xB0) {
      description = `CC ch${(data[0] & 0x0F) + 1}`;
    }

    const message: MidiMessage = {
      timestamp,
      direction,
      port,
      data,
      hex,
      description
    };

    this.messages.push(message);

    // Console output
    const timeStr = new Date(timestamp).toISOString().split('T')[1].split('.')[0];
    const arrow = direction === 'TO_DEVICE' ? 'â†’' : 'â†';
    const icon = data[0] === 0xF0 ? 'ğŸ”¥' : '  ';

    console.log(`${icon} ${timeStr} ${arrow} [${port.padEnd(25)}] ${description.padEnd(30)} ${hex.substring(0, 80)}${hex.length > 80 ? '...' : ''}`);
  }

  private getInputPorts(): string[] {
    const input = new midi.Input();
    const ports: string[] = [];
    const count = input.getPortCount();

    for (let i = 0; i < count; i++) {
      ports.push(input.getPortName(i));
    }

    input.closePort();
    return ports;
  }

  private getOutputPorts(): string[] {
    const output = new midi.Output();
    const ports: string[] = [];
    const count = output.getPortCount();

    for (let i = 0; i < count; i++) {
      ports.push(output.getPortName(i));
    }

    output.closePort();
    return ports;
  }

  async stop() {
    console.log('\n\nâœ“ Capture complete!');

    // Save to file
    const filename = `midi-spy-${Date.now()}.json`;
    writeFileSync(filename, JSON.stringify(this.messages, null, 2));
    console.log(`ğŸ’¾ Saved ${this.messages.length} messages to ${filename}`);

    // Summary
    const toDevice = this.messages.filter(m => m.direction === 'TO_DEVICE');
    const fromDevice = this.messages.filter(m => m.direction === 'FROM_DEVICE');

    console.log(`\nğŸ“Š Summary:`);
    console.log(`   TO device: ${toDevice.length} messages`);
    console.log(`   FROM device: ${fromDevice.length} messages`);

    // Close ports
    this.virtualIn?.closePort();
    this.virtualOut?.closePort();
    this.realIn?.closePort();
    this.realOut?.closePort();
  }
}

// Main
const spy = new MidiSpy();

spy.start().catch(console.error);

process.on('SIGINT', async () => {
  console.log('\nğŸ›‘ Stopping spy...');
  await spy.stop();
  process.exit(0);
});
```

Result:

```

     3â†’## Executive Summary
     4â†’
     5â†’Since our current SysEx implementation is not successfully writing data to the device (slots remain unchanged despite successful message transmission), we need to reverse-engineer the actual MIDI protocol by intercepting and analyzing real communication between the Launch Control XL 3 and the official Novation web editor.
     6â†’
     7â†’This workplan outlines creating a comprehensive MIDI spy harness that will:
     8â†’1. Intercept all MIDI messages between the device and web editor

   559â†’## Critical Findings - Session 3
   560â†’
   561â†’### Major Discovery: Excessive LED Control Messages
   562â†’
   563â†’During live testing with Playwright automation and MIDI monitoring, we discovered a critical implementation issue:
   564â†’
   565â†’#### The Problem
   566â†’Our library sends **hundreds of excessive LED control messages** after SysEx operations:
   567â†’- Pattern: `0x11 0x78` messages repeated 200+ times
   568â†’- These messages flood the MIDI communication channel
   569â†’- Likely causing device to ignore or fail processing legitimate commands
   570â†’- The web editor does NOT send these messages
   571â†’
   572â†’#### Evidence Captured
   573â†’\```json
   574â†’{
   575â†’  "timestamp": 1759157043879,
   576â†’  "portName": "Launch Control XL3",
   577â†’  "messageType": "cc",
   578â†’  "rawData": [177, 120, 0],
   579â†’  "hexData": "0xb1 0x78 0x00",
   580â†’  "parsedData": {
   581â†’    "channel": 1,
   582â†’    "controller": 120,
   583â†’    "value": 0,
   584â†’    "_type": "cc"
   585â†’  }
   586â†’}
   587â†’// ... repeated 200+ times
   588â†’\```
   589â†’
   590â†’#### Web Editor Protocol (Correct Implementation)
   591â†’The official web editor sends clean, minimal SysEx messages:
   592â†’\```
   593â†’Write command: 0xf0 0x00 0x20 0x29 0x02 0x15 0x05 0x00 0x15 0x00 0x06 0xf7
   594â†’\```
   595â†’- No excessive LED messages
   596â†’- Clean, focused communication
   597â†’- Device responds correctly
   598â†’
   599â†’### Test Session Details
   600â†’
   601â†’Successfully automated the Novation web editor using Playwright MCP:
   602â†’1. Navigated to https://components.novationmusic.com/launch-control-xl-3/custom-modes
   603â†’2. Created new custom mode
   604â†’3. Named Encoder 1 as "TestVolume1"
   605â†’4. Sent configuration to device slot 1
   606â†’5. Captured all MIDI traffic during operation
   607â†’
   608â†’### Root Cause Analysis
   609â†’
   610â†’The excessive `0x11 0x78` messages appear to be:
   611â†’- **Controller 120 (0x78)**: All Sound Off MIDI message
   612â†’- **Channel 2 (0xb1)**: Being sent on MIDI channel 2
   613â†’- **Unnecessary repetition**: Sent hundreds of times after each operation
   614â†’- **Blocking legitimate traffic**: Flooding prevents proper SysEx processing
   615â†’
   616â†’### Required Fixes
   617â†’
   618â†’1. **Remove excessive LED control messages** from SysEx operations
   619â†’2. **Audit all MIDI message sending** to ensure no unnecessary traffic
   620â†’3. **Match web editor's clean protocol** - only send required messages
   621â†’4. **Test with monitoring** to verify clean communication
   622â†’
   623â†’### Implementation Recommendations
   624â†’
   625â†’Based on our spy harness findings, the following changes are required:
   626â†’
   627â†’1. **Locate and Remove LED Flooding Code**
   628â†’   - Search for code sending CC 120 (0x78) messages
   629â†’   - Remove or comment out the loop causing repetition
   630â†’   - Likely in LED update or device sync functions
   631â†’
   632â†’2. **Review SysEx Write Implementation**
   633â†’   - Compare our SysEx format with captured web editor format
   634â†’   - Web editor uses: `0xf0 0x00 0x20 0x29 0x02 0x15 0x05 0x00 0x15 0x00 0x06 0xf7`
   635â†’   - Ensure we're not adding unnecessary wrapper messages
   636â†’
   637â†’3. **Testing Protocol**
   638â†’   - Run MIDI monitor during all tests
   639â†’   - Verify only necessary messages are sent
   640â†’   - Compare message count with web editor (should be minimal)

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-1-20250805)**_

Perfect! The workplan shows we already have `utils/midi-monitor.ts` and discovered a critical issue - excessive LED control messages. The workplan also notes that we need to capture the COMPLETE bidirectional conversation. 

Looking at the critical findings, it says the web editor sends:
```
Write command: 0xf0 0x00 0x20 0x29 0x02 0x15 0x05 0x00 0x15 0x00 0x06 0xf7
```

But wait - that's just the 12-byte acknowledgment, not the write command! The actual write uses 0x45 as you corrected earlier.

Let me look for existing captures to compare with our round-trip test. First, let me check if we have any saved capture files:

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-1-20250805)**_

Tool use: **Bash** Check for existing MIDI capture files

`ls -la midi-captures/ 2>/dev/null || echo "No midi-captures directory found"`

Result:

```
total 16

Result:

```
#!/usr/bin/env tsx

import * as easymidi from 'easymidi';
import { Sysex } from 'easymidi';

const MIDI_PORT = 'LCXL3 1 MIDI Out';

console.log(`Listening to MIDI port: ${MIDI_PORT}\n`);

try {
  const input = new easymidi.Input(MIDI_PORT);

  input.on('sysex', (sysex: Sysex) => {
    console.log('SysEx:', sysex.bytes.map(b => '0x' + b.toString(16).padStart(2, '0')).join(' '));
  });

  input.on('cc', (msg: any) => {
    console.log('CC:', msg);
  });
```

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-1-20250805)**_

```md
# Utils Directory Tool Guide

## Official Tools (from WORKPLAN-SPY-HARNESS.md)

### Phase 1 - Passive MIDI Monitoring
- **`midi-monitor.ts`** - Main passive MIDI monitoring tool
  - Captures all MIDI traffic without interference
  - Supports device filtering and verbose logging
  - Saves sessions to JSON files

- **`monitor-session-analyzer.ts`** - Analyzes captured MIDI sessions
  - Pattern recognition and comparison
  - Generates detailed analysis reports

- **`test-midi-monitor.ts`** - Test script for midi-monitor
  - Verifies monitor functionality

- **`midi-monitor-web.html`** - Web-based MIDI monitor using Web MIDI API
  - Browser-based alternative to Node.js monitor

### Phase 2 - Web Editor Automation
- **`playwright-test-actions.ts`** - Library of test actions for web editor
  - Defines automated actions for Playwright

- **`capture-web-editor-write.ts`** - Playwright automation for web editor
  - Automates Novation web editor to capture traffic

### Test Utilities
- **`test-round-trip.ts`** - Tests write->read verification
- **`test-web-editor-protocol.ts`** - Tests web editor protocol
- **`test-fixed-write.ts`** - Tests SysEx write with 0x45
- **`test-simple-command.ts`** - Simple command testing

### Early/Simple Test Tools (kept for reference)
- `midi-listener.ts` - Simple MIDI listener (superseded by midi-monitor.ts)
- `test-control-names.ts` - Early control name testing
- `test-fetch-custom-mode-node.ts` - Custom mode fetching tests
- `test-factory-mode-copy.ts` - Factory mode copying tests

## DO NOT CREATE DUPLICATES
When working on MIDI monitoring or capturing, use the existing `midi-monitor.ts` tool.
It's the official implementation from the WORKPLAN-SPY-HARNESS.md.

## Important Note
The midi-monitor currently only captures messages FROM the device (output ports).
To capture messages TO the device, we need to either:
1. Create virtual MIDI ports to intercept traffic
2. Use the web editor with known-good messages for comparison
```

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-1-20250805)**_

I see the issue - the midi-monitor uses `easymidi.getInputs()` which returns the ports we can read FROM. These are actually the device's OUTPUT ports (confusingly named). To capture messages going TO the device, we need to create virtual ports that act as a proxy.

Let me update the midi-monitor to add virtual port interception capability:

    88â†’   * Start virtual port interception mode
    89â†’   * This creates virtual ports that intercept traffic between web editor and device
    90â†’   */
    91â†’  async startInterceptionMode(): Promise<void> {
    92â†’    if (this.isRunning) {
    93â†’      throw new Error('Monitor is already running');
    94â†’    }
    95â†’
    96â†’    console.log('ğŸµ Starting MIDI Monitor - Interception Mode');
    97â†’    console.log('â•'.repeat(60));
    98â†’
    99â†’    // Create virtual ports
   100â†’    this.virtualIn = new easymidi.Input();
   101â†’    this.virtualOut = new easymidi.Output();
   102â†’
   103â†’    // Open virtual ports with names that web editor will connect to
   104â†’    this.virtualIn.openVirtualPort('LCXL3 Virtual MIDI In');
   105â†’    this.virtualOut.openVirtualPort('LCXL3 Virtual MIDI Out');
   106â†’

   110â†’

   112â†’    const inputs = easymidi.getInputs();
   113â†’    const outputs = easymidi.getOutputs();
   114â†’
   115â†’    const realInIdx = inputs.findIndex(p => p.includes('LCXL3 1 MIDI Out'));
   116â†’    const realOutIdx = outputs.findIndex(p => p.includes('LCXL3 1 MIDI In'));
   117â†’
   118â†’    if (realInIdx >= 0 && realOutIdx >= 0) {
   119â†’      this.realIn = new easymidi.Input(inputs[realInIdx]);
   120â†’      this.realOut = new easymidi.Output(outputs[realOutIdx]);
   121â†’
   122â†’      console.log('âœ… Connected to real device:');
   123â†’      console.log(`   - ${inputs[realInIdx]}`);
   124â†’      console.log(`   - ${outputs[realOutIdx]}`);
   125â†’    } else {
   126â†’      throw new Error('Could not find real LCXL3 device ports');
   127â†’    }
   128â†’
   129â†’    this.startTime = Date.now();
   130â†’    this.isRunning = true;
   131â†’
   132â†’    // Set up message forwarding and capture
   133â†’    this.setupInterception();
   134â†’

   136â†’    console.log('âš ï¸  Configure web editor to use:');
   137â†’    console.log('   Input: LCXL3 Virtual MIDI Out');
   138â†’    console.log('   Output: LCXL3 Virtual MIDI In');
   139â†’    console.log('\nâ¹ï¸  Press Ctrl+C to stop and save session');

   143â†’  }
   144â†’
   145â†’  /**
   146â†’   * Set up message interception and forwarding
   147â†’   */
   148â†’  private setupInterception(): void {
   149â†’    // Intercept messages FROM web editor TO device
   150â†’    this.virtualIn!.on('message', (deltaTime: number, message: number[]) => {
   151â†’      this.captureMessage('WEBâ†’DEVICE', 'message', message, { direction: 'TO_DEVICE' });
   152â†’      // Forward to real device
   153â†’      if (this.realOut) {
   154â†’        this.realOut.sendMessage(message);
   155â†’      }
   156â†’    });
   157â†’
   158â†’    this.virtualIn!.on('sysex', (msg: any) => {
   159â†’      const data = msg.bytes || msg.data || [];
   160â†’      this.captureMessage('WEBâ†’DEVICE', 'sysex', data, { direction: 'TO_DEVICE' });
   161â†’      // Forward to real device
   162â†’      if (this.realOut && data.length > 0) {
   163â†’        this.realOut.sendMessage(data);
   164â†’      }
   165â†’    });
   166â†’
   167â†’    // Intercept messages FROM device TO web editor
   168â†’    this.realIn!.on('message', (deltaTime: number, message: number[]) => {
   169â†’      this.captureMessage('DEVICEâ†’WEB', 'message', message, { direction: 'FROM_DEVICE' });
   170â†’      // Forward to web editor
   171â†’      if (this.virtualOut) {
   172â†’        this.virtualOut.sendMessage(message);
   173â†’      }
